headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Another maybe follow-up question quickly on Aerospace. When you compare this release to your last release last quarter, and you look at the estimated potential contract value, it went up by almost $1 billion. Can you help us understand what that means? An
componenttext: Another maybe follow-up question quickly on Aerospace. When you compare this release to your last release last quarter, and you look at the estimated potential contract value, it went up by almost $1 billion. Can you help us understand what that means? And what gets thrown in that pile? And why it would go up by $1 billion?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me ask Jason to give you a little color on that.
componenttext: Yes. Let me ask Jason to give you a little color on that.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So, Ron, one of the last comments that I made was around this area and it -- typically in the estimated potential contract value bucket for the Defense business is that's clearly contract options and IDIQ potential value. For Aerospace, it hold a number o
componenttext: So, Ron, one of the last comments that I made was around this area and it -- typically in the estimated potential contract value bucket for the Defense business is that's clearly contract options and IDIQ potential value. For Aerospace, it hold a number of items to include options for aircraft as well as longer-term arrangements that we have with individual customers, so where deliveries may be further out in the delivery queue and spread out in the backlog. So as I mentioned, we did have, in the fourth quarter, a fairly large contract signed up with an existing commercial customer. It was valued at just over $1 billion. It's a multi-aircraft, multiyear arrangement that spans out over several years. That did not go into the firm backlog because that order is actually subject to that customer's board approval coming up later this quarter. So we expect that to happen this quarter, and will move into the firm backlog and be counted as traditional orders at the time, but given the maturity of that and where it was in the quarter, that's why we put it in the -- as we typically are conservative on these notions, we put it in the potential contract value bucket versus in the firm backlog till we get to that firm order.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And if I may do 1 follow-up for Phebe. When you think about the current political environment and what that means for defense spending, and how do you parse through that? Like it seems like there's just a lot of uncertainty and volatility goi
componenttext: Okay. Great. And if I may do 1 follow-up for Phebe. When you think about the current political environment and what that means for defense spending, and how do you parse through that? Like it seems like there's just a lot of uncertainty and volatility going on. So in your experience, how do you think about it?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- some of the political contretemps haven't affected the Defense spending. As -- and in fact, Defense spending has been increasing in this environment. So we are quite comfortable that we're going to see through our, at least, initial planning
componenttext: Well, the -- some of the political contretemps haven't affected the Defense spending. As -- and in fact, Defense spending has been increasing in this environment. So we are quite comfortable that we're going to see through our, at least, initial planning horizon, very nice funding for all of our key programs. So I haven't seen too much perturbation as a result of some of the extant issues with respect to the overall budget impacting Defense.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019

componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Spingarn of Crédit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Phebe or Jason, I wanted to see if we could dig a little bit more into the margin pressure you expect in the front end of '19. And what you saw in the back end of '18? How do we parse the pressure between the completion issues, Phebe, that you cited at Je
componenttext: Phebe or Jason, I wanted to see if we could dig a little bit more into the margin pressure you expect in the front end of '19. And what you saw in the back end of '18? How do we parse the pressure between the completion issues, Phebe, that you cited at Jet Aviation, just a general learning curve and conversions you're doing on 500s and 600s? And specifically, Nordam, where does Nordam factor into this? And how quickly do you get a lift as that problem diminishes?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So let's take it in a reverse order. We've got the nacelle line well under control. The cost performance has been quite good, and as I mentioned in my remarks, we've had to spool back up the supply chain. That is the pacing item with respect to our timing
componenttext: So let's take it in a reverse order. We've got the nacelle line well under control. The cost performance has been quite good, and as I mentioned in my remarks, we've had to spool back up the supply chain. That is the pacing item with respect to our timing of our deliveries. But the supply chain is doing well and it's just going to take them a while to begin to have the capacity and the throughput and product to feed our demand. So I will see a little bit of slowness on that, on the delivery of nacelles, but as we get into the second half, that will have completely resolved, and we will be in full rate production throughout the supply chain. So we're quite pleased with that. The margin compression, it has been something we've been talking to you all for some time about. As you all know, the first lot of airplanes, in this case, we're talking about the G500 carry very little margins. Those airplanes will ramp up -- continue to ramp up that production in first quarter, second quarter and as we move from that initial lot that carry those lower margins, then you'll see some -- we will see some margin expansion on that line. The 600 will come in at slightly higher entry margins simply because of the disproportionate amount of test cost and R&D cost borne by the 500. And then we'll see with respect to the margins. The completion business at Jet, we had a problem this year really on the operating side. We have fixed that. And going forward, we're comfortable that they will do better this year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So Jet's not really part of the '19 pressure.
componenttext: So Jet's not really part of the '19 pressure.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. Well, it is -- no, they're not. They will do better this year because of the affirmative and proactive steps they took in '18. So the pressure is mostly about mix.
componenttext: No. Well, it is -- no, they're not. They will do better this year because of the affirmative and proactive steps they took in '18. So the pressure is mostly about mix.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And do you think -- once you're through this year, do you recover to the old margins at Aerospace?
componenttext: And do you think -- once you're through this year, do you recover to the old margins at Aerospace?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Look, we'll have as we continue to come down our learning curve. We finish up a lot of the 500, the first lot of 500 airplanes, the first lot of 600 airplanes, you can expect us to come quickly down our learning curve. And I -- as I have mentioned in my r
componenttext: Look, we'll have as we continue to come down our learning curve. We finish up a lot of the 500, the first lot of 500 airplanes, the first lot of 600 airplanes, you can expect us to come quickly down our learning curve. And I -- as I have mentioned in my remarks, we'll see some earnings and margin expansion in '20 and then really quite nice expansion and considerable earnings growth thereafter as we have completed all of those 2 transitions. So I'm not going to predict exactly where we end up on new airplanes with respect to terminal margins here. But you should expect us to continue the strong operating performance you have seen from us. We know how to build these airplanes. Low-cost, high-quality provider. We're good at that.

componenttext: I was hoping we could get some color around the Canadian LAV program that was weighing on the conversion this year. You probably had maybe $1 billion of revenue on that program. I'm curious are you getting any cash on the program on an ongoing basis? And what would the conversion have looked like if not for the progress delays?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So let me give you some context here, Myles. This is a valid contract that all parties to that contract have repeatedly and recently attested to their commitment to honor that contract. The Canadian government fully understands the importance of our high-
componenttext: So let me give you some context here, Myles. This is a valid contract that all parties to that contract have repeatedly and recently attested to their commitment to honor that contract. The Canadian government fully understands the importance of our high-end manufacturing and engineering talent in London, Ontario and the robust supply chain that we have throughout the country. Our payment issue got caught up in a larger, international political issue, diplomatic issue. That's why we got some payment last year. Those diplomatic contretemps affected the -- slowed the payment that we would have otherwise have anticipated. So that will resolve, it's a timing issue. And we're quite comfortable and quite confident that, that will resolve. Just at a slower rate than we had anticipated.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Phebe, I wanted to ask in -- on Gulfstream, I thought you had implied in the third quarter that the book-to-bill would get close to 1. So if you just comment on what might have happened so, since we wound up somewhat less than that?
componenttext: Yes. Phebe, I wanted to ask in -- on Gulfstream, I thought you had implied in the third quarter that the book-to-bill would get close to 1. So if you just comment on what might have happened so, since we wound up somewhat less than that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I believe, George, what I said was that the orders would be better in the fourth quarter than they were in the third quarter. In fact, they were. And the book-to-bill was nice, particularly, I think, particularly, when you look at the additional delivery,
componenttext: I believe, George, what I said was that the orders would be better in the fourth quarter than they were in the third quarter. In fact, they were. And the book-to-bill was nice, particularly, I think, particularly, when you look at the additional delivery, a considerable number of additional deliveries that we had in the fourth quarter. But the quarterly book-to-bill, if you go back and look at Gulfstream, Aerospace tends to have some lumpiness. But we had very nice order activity last year, and the fourth quarter was about what we anticipated, orders would be better than the third quarter. And I would also point out that we've got a -- Jason talked about it at some length, a $1 billion order with a customer that, once it gets cleared by its board, moves into backlog. So I consider that a -- we had a good order quarter.

componenttext: So, Phebe, I believe, Mark Burns, who runs Gulfstream, has said at some point, you'll have a competitor to the Global 7500 in the market. And you obviously have an opportunity back where the 450 was and you obviously have probably taken a little bit longer than you expected on certifying the G600s. So if we think about R&D, was that high in the fourth -- high -- relatively high in the fourth quarter? And what comment can you give us in terms of what sort of a drag that will be on 2019?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So let me just gently tease you a bit about not trafficking in, what I call, rumor intelligence, rumint. So with that cautionary note, our certification has come along quite nicely. As I told you, it's a little slower than we anticipated. This is a detail
componenttext: So let me just gently tease you a bit about not trafficking in, what I call, rumor intelligence, rumint. So with that cautionary note, our certification has come along quite nicely. As I told you, it's a little slower than we anticipated. This is a detailed and appropriately robust process that unfortunately got impacted by the shutdown. And I apologize for my early optimism, but originally, our plan, our internal plan was first quarter. And we think that because of the perturbations of the shutdown, that's going to move into the second quarter. Jason will talk about the R&D.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Cai, the R&D for the quarter was essentially flat year-over-year. It was up a little bit sequentially from the third quarter if you go back and look at that data, call it, by roughly $20 million or so. I think for the year, we ended up right around 1
componenttext: Yes. Cai, the R&D for the quarter was essentially flat year-over-year. It was up a little bit sequentially from the third quarter if you go back and look at that data, call it, by roughly $20 million or so. I think for the year, we ended up right around 1.5% of sales for total company-sponsored R&D. So I don't think high or low in any anomalous way, and I think we expect to see, as we have in the past, a continued steady drip, and Phebe alluded to it on R&D as we continue the pipeline of new product introductions and technology introductions. So I don't think anything anomalous up or down.

componenttext: Phebe, just thinking about some of the good news that's going on in Marine and just thinking back to kind of your longer-term targets there, you've had some really nice contract wins since those projections. So is this volume falling outside of that kind of scope for the 2020 targets? Or is this delivering you some additional upside? Because it seems like you're tracking ahead of that. Just some additional color there would be great.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So the preponderance of the growth we're going to see is at Electric Boat and submarines. We've gotten some nice wins at Bath. I think they've got 11 DDG 51s in their backlog now and they'll continue to turn through those. NASSCO has started its first con
componenttext: So the preponderance of the growth we're going to see is at Electric Boat and submarines. We've gotten some nice wins at Bath. I think they've got 11 DDG 51s in their backlog now and they'll continue to turn through those. NASSCO has started its first containership, Matson, about 2 months early. They're working on the next oiler and they've got that extraordinarily versatile platform in the ESB. So they have done nicely with slow, steady growth, but the real growth driver is Electric Boat. And you see that in 2 respects. Both on the -- we've got the Virginia-Class 2-year volume in Block IV, and then Block V is a, as I noted in my remarks, really a significant upgrade into the performance. And it is a -- let me just leave it at that. It is -- it will drive additional revenue, incremental revenue. And then the advent of the Columbia, which we begin early construction in next year. So this is a steady growth engine for us as we've been saying for some time. Very pleased with them.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Phebe, just another question on sort of product development as you think about sort of the long term and some lessons learned on the 650. You talked a lot about speed before as being an important value proposition to your new customers for these high-end
componenttext: Phebe, just another question on sort of product development as you think about sort of the long term and some lessons learned on the 650. You talked a lot about speed before as being an important value proposition to your new customers for these high-end products. Is there any sort of evolving, sort of appetite for new capabilities beyond just speed as you think about product development for the next 5 to 10 years? Is it like runway access, access to remote regions, anything like that? Or is it really just sort of like a speed concept to sort of the next value proposition?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Speed is important, but as you can well imagine, we continue to upgrade and innovate around the avionics, cabin comfort and the engines, both in fuel efficiency, decibel levels and -- and look, these airplanes are getting better and better and better acro
componenttext: Speed is important, but as you can well imagine, we continue to upgrade and innovate around the avionics, cabin comfort and the engines, both in fuel efficiency, decibel levels and -- and look, these airplanes are getting better and better and better across the spectrum. Speed, for us, is an important commodity because people's time is precious. So you're quite right, to posit that, that has been our focus but it is by no means the single and exclusive focus.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: Good morning, everyone and welcome to the General Dynamics First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note, today's event is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to Howard Rubel, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jaime, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics First Quarter 2019 Conference Call. Any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks
componenttext: Thank you, Jaime, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics First Quarter 2019 Conference Call. Any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings. With that, it's my pleasure to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Howard, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported earnings of $2.56 per diluted share on revenue just shy of $9.3 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net income of $745 million. Revenue was up 23% against the first q
componenttext:
Thanks, Howard, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported earnings of $2.56 per diluted share on revenue just shy of $9.3 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net income of $745 million. Revenue was up 23% against the first quarter of 2018 due in large part to the acquisition of CSRA. However, without CSRA, revenue was up an impressive 9.6% on a purely organic basis. In fact, there was organic revenue growth across all 5 operating segments. 
EPS of $2.56 was $0.14 better than consensus. It would appear that revenue was some $400 million higher than anticipated by the sell side, and operating earnings were about $40 million higher. Operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion were our just ahead of the year ago results, despite modest declines at Aerospace, Marine and Combat Systems. The results benefited from the combination of CSRA with GDIT. 
While the operating margin of 10.9% in the quarter was good, it did not compare favorably to last year's stellar first quarter of 13.4%, which was before the inclusion of amortization from the CSRA transaction. 
Net earnings are down [ $54 ] million over the same quarter in 2018. Higher interest expense, somewhat higher taxes were the cause of the lower net income. It follows that earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.09 below the first quarter 2018, a 3% drop. 
Apart from the impressive revenue growth, an important part of the story in the quarter was order intake and growth in backlog. Total backlog grew to $69.2 billion, an increase of $1.34 billion compared to the end of last year. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, the book-to-bill for the company was an impressive 1.2, broken down to 1.1:1 for Defense and 1.4:1 for Aerospace. 
Let me discuss each group and provide some color where appropriate. First Aerospace. Aerospace revenue of $2.2 billion was $450 million or 22.7% ahead of the year ago period. This was attributable in large part to the delivery of 7 G500s in the quarter and a solid increase in service revenue. The moderately lower operating earnings were related to the mix shift at Gulfstream from the delivery of the G500s. These planes carry the burden of the test program and retrofit, as we previously advised. The margins on the aircraft will improve markedly through the year. 
At year-end, we had indicated that Aerospace margins for the first 2 quarters would be in the mid-14% range, up somewhat from the 14.1% rate in the final period of 2018. At 14.6%, the margin was fractionally better than that indication. Excluding the adverse impact of margins from preowned sales, margins would have been about 40 basis points better. Based on our delivery profile and cost improvement, we continue to expect overall margins to improve, particularly so in the second half of the year. 
On the order front, activity in the quarter was very good. The book-to-bill at Aerospace was 1.4:1 dollar denominated. The Gulfstream book-to-bill was even better. We grew the backlog for the G650 and also expanded the G500 and 600 backlog. For the trailing 12 months, Aerospace book-to-bill was about 1.1:1. You can see more information on the quarter's deliveries and orders in Exhibit J to the press release. 
We anticipate that G600 will be certified late June, but timing is difficult to predict given the FAA's rigorous review process. Nonetheless, we expect certification of the 600 this quarter or early next. The deliveries will remain on track for the second half. 
While the pacing [indiscernible] for deliveries on the 500 and 600 is our ability to deliver nacelle, this is becoming less of an issue, as you can discern from deliveries of the G500 in the fourth quarter and the last quarter. Nacelle costs are increasingly under control, and we are producing very good quality. We expect all schedule issues to be behind us by midyear. 
So forgive me this commercial plug, but earlier this month, the G650 shattered a record for speed and range, demonstrating it unrivaled performance. The aircraft flew 8,379 nautical miles from Singapore to Tucson in 15 hours and 23 minutes, averaging Mach 0.85, beating the record just a few weeks earlier by the competitor's aircraft by 44 minutes. It is also interesting that the G650 traveled during that flight approximately 227 nautical miles further than the competitor's aircraft in considerably less time. This is to our knowledge the longest distance ever flown by any business aviation aircraft. This is of particular interest to customers who think that the range and speed at that range is of vital importance. 
Next, Combat. At Combat, revenue of $1.6 billion was [ 13.6% ] above the year ago quarter. On the other hand come operating earnings declined $18 million with an operating margin of 12.6%. Mix was a large factor behind the results. There was strong growth in the program and a ramp-up of Mobile Protected Firepower, another new program. Stryker volumes were down, but we ascribe that to timing. Munitions also delivered growth. We also took a onetime charge in the quarter related to the disposition of a legal dispute over the closeout of a lease at one of our former European operating sites. Absent that onetime item, earnings for this segment would have been up year-over-year. 
The diplomatic issues that have slowed production on the international vehicle program in Canada are in the process of being resolved. Once resolved, between the 2 countries, we will see a reduction in operating working capital and a corresponding increase in cash received. Backlog for this segment is lumpy with the fourth quarter traditionally seeing the highest order activity and the first quarter is the slowest. This year is no exception. The $2.2 billion in orders received in Q4 followed by the approximately $1.2 billion in orders received this quarter is a good line of sight for the production planning and continuous improvement methodology. 
Of note, Stryker backlog grew in the first quarter, and the Army added funding to the [indiscernible], the next generation of the Abrams' main battle tank. Stryker is a very flexible platform, and the Army continues to find additional systems and weapons that we are integrating onto the vehicles. Integration of new capabilities on to our vehicles leverages our investment. Our intimate knowledge of the platform and ensures that the Army receives its programs reliably and affordably. 
We also continue to see opportunities to expand the ordnance and tactical munitions business as the Army refreshes its ordinance and ammo stockpile. We continue to have significant international opportunities throughout Middle and Eastern Europe as well as the Pacific regions. 
Next, Marine Systems. Marine revenues of $2.1 billion was up slightly and operating earnings of $180 million were down $4 million against the year ago quarter. Operating margins were 8.7% with our guidance for the year at 8.5%. We are modestly ahead of target. We have delivered the 17th ship of the Virginia class program and have another 11 in various stages of construction. With respect to Columbia, we are 97% complete with the detailed design and nearly 43% complete with the construction design drawings. We will be at 83% complete at the start of construction, far in excess of historical design completion metrics for any class of warship. We have begun long-lead material construction on Columbia and will begin full construction of the first ship late next year. 
In response to the significant increase in demand from our Navy customer across all 3 of our shipyards, we continue to invest in each of our yards with particular efforts at Electric Boat to prepare for the higher production associated with Block V of the Virginia program and the new Columbia ballistic-missile submarine. As you may recall, both Columbia and the Block V represent a significant increased in size and performance, requiring additional manufacturing capacity and different logistics infrastructure to transport the larger modules from [indiscernible] point to the waterfront [indiscernible] for final assembly and test. 
CapEx in 2018 for Marine Systems was $243 million, more than double its depreciation for the year. For 2019, we again expect the Marine segment to command the largest share of our capital budget, about half of our entire CapEx. So suffice it to say that we are poised to support our Navy customers as they seek to increase the size of their fleet. 
Next, Information Technology. For the quarter, IT generated revenue of $2.2 billion and operating earnings of $156 million with an operating margin of 7.2%. Since the numbers for the first quarter 2018 did not include CSRA, comparisons to the year ago quarter are not meaningful. 
Revenue of $2.2 billion is up by over $1 billion, but is down about $200 million sequentially, over half of which is attributable to the divestiture of the call centers and the remaining to the winding down of several mature programs replaced by the ramp-up of new programs. Margin of 7.2% is lower than Q4 due to mix, but a bit better than Q2 and Q3 of 2018. 
If you look at our EBITDA margin, it is 12.4%, including state and local taxes in the operating results. If these taxes were carried below the line, as in the case of the most competitors in this segment, it would add approximately 50 basis points to our results. This places the business in the best-in-class category for its industry. 
The integration has gone well and is a bit ahead of our plan we put in place last year. We are taking the best of the 2 legacy companies and building a highly competitive enterprise, with the scale and the resources to create value for our customers and our shareholders. GDIT's book-to-bill for the quarter was 1.1:1; and for the trailing 4 quarters, it is over 1:1. This business is growing and is positioned for growth going forward. 
The first quarter includes some notable wins, a $490 million contract from [indiscernible] to support Pentagon network infrastructure, a $125 million for helicopter training and simulation at Fort [indiscernible], $580 million for several classified programs and a myriad of additional wins across the portfolio. 
Finally, for Mission Systems, revenue rose by 5.5% compared to the year ago quarter, while operating earnings of $148 million were $2 million higher than the first quarter of last year, with a 50 basis point decrement in operating margins attributable solely to mix. Book-to-bill for the quarter was 1x following 1:1 book-to-bill for this -- for each of the last 2 years. As you can see, we ended the quarter with a backlog of $5.3 billion, essentially level with the prior quarter and with the year ago quarter. Demand was broad-based across many of the space and naval programs. Army ground systems activity was particularly strong. 
So in my view, we are off to a good start to the year. The story in the fourth quarter was about revenue and backlog growth. Orders [ at ] $10.7 billion across our businesses provide us with good operational visibility. Our ongoing focus on productivity provides the opportunity to deliver very good results. As we begin this quarter, we expect our second quarter performance to be very similar to the first quarter from an EPS perspective. 
You may recall that we do not, as a practice, change guidance at the end of the first quarter. It is our practice to give you a full review of our expectations at midyear -- at midpoint during the year. Suffice it to say that we are a bit ahead of the operating plan upon which our guidance was based. As always, will work to consolidate our improvement and strive to continue to improve our results. 
Let me turn this over to Jason for additional commentary and then take your questions.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. Net interest expense in the quarter was $117 million versus $27 million in the first quarter of 2018. The increase in 2019 is due to the debt we issued to finance the acquisition of CSRA. We are also carrying more comme
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. Net interest expense in the quarter was $117 million versus $27 million in the first quarter of 2018. The increase in 2019 is due to the debt we issued to finance the acquisition of CSRA. We are also carrying more commercial paper than anticipated due to delayed payments on one of our large international vehicle programs in Canada. Our free cash flow of negative $976 million was impacted by these payment delays, and as we've discussed previously, this is a timing item. 
On the capital deployment front, capital expenditures of $181 million in the quarter were up about 75% from the year ago quarter, as we invest in our shipyards to support the significant growth that's on the horizon. We still expect this year to be the peak at approximately 3% of revenues and returning to the 2% range thereafter. 
In the quarter, we paid $268 million in dividends, and we spent $86 million on the repurchase of 525,000 of our shares. We plan to acquire enough shares in 2019 to ensure there is no dilution from the exercise of employee stock options. Otherwise, we anticipate deploying the balance of our free cash flow this year to pay down our short-term borrowings. 
We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $673 million on the balance sheet and a net debt position of $12.9 billion. Our effective tax rate was 18.6% for the quarter, which is consistent with our full year tax rate guidance. As Phebe noted, order activity and backlog were a particularly strong story in the quarter, as 4 of our 5 segment posted a book-to-bill of 1:1 or greater, even as we grew almost 10% organically. 
On that note, I think it bears a reminder that not all companies report book-to-bill on the same basis. We calculate this measure based on a firm backlog as reported under generally accepted accounting principles, excluding the value associated with IDIQ contracts. That's, of course, most relevant to Mission Systems and GDIT, each of which had a book-to-bill of 1:1 or greater, even under the more conservative GAAP definition. 
We finished the quarter with a total backlog of $69.2 billion, that's up 2% over year-end 2018 and up 11% over this time a year ago. The total potential contract value including options and IDIQ contracts was $103 billion, consistent with year-end and up almost 18% over year ago. 
As one final item I'd like to highlight, we adopted the new lease accounting standard effective January 1 of this year on a perspective basis. We recorded a $1.4 billion liability for our operating leases along with a corresponding asset. This creates a visible change in our other assets and liabilities on the balance sheet, but otherwise has no impact on our net earnings or cash flows. 
Howard, that concludes my remarks, I'll turn it back over to you for Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Doug Harned from Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Doug Harned from Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get a little bit better understanding on the margin trajectory at Gulfstream. You talked before in the last quarter about the lower margins at the beginning of the year and likely, very attractive margins when you get out in Q4. Could you give
componenttext: I wanted to get a little bit better understanding on the margin trajectory at Gulfstream. You talked before in the last quarter about the lower margins at the beginning of the year and likely, very attractive margins when you get out in Q4. Could you give us a sense of what's behind that trajectory. And are those higher margins at the end of the year, are those the sort of normal margin that we might expect going forward beyond this year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: As I said in my remarks, margin rate is largely attributed to the mix. And as we've talked about fairly frequently, that mix is driven by the increased deliveries on the G500, which carries a lower margin in that first accounting lot, but we're are going
componenttext: As I said in my remarks, margin rate is largely attributed to the mix. And as we've talked about fairly frequently, that mix is driven by the increased deliveries on the G500, which carries a lower margin in that first accounting lot, but we're are going to be through that in the second quarter. And look, I think, we've been pretty -- quite transparent about this change in mix. We'll work our way through as we deliver more G500s and the G600s as they enter into service with good margin. So when I think about it, our margins will improve throughout the year, and as we going into next year, our performance will get even better and better. As we hit full rate production on the 500 and 600 and continue to come down our learning curve.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then when you get out there and the 500 and 600 are mature, is it possible to give us a sense of how you might think about that between -- for the G550 and the G650 mature margins? Where will the 500 and 600 shakeout?
componenttext: And then when you get out there and the 500 and 600 are mature, is it possible to give us a sense of how you might think about that between -- for the G550 and the G650 mature margins? Where will the 500 and 600 shakeout?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: The G650, nothing's going to come close to that for, I think, all the reasons that you understand. But it is our expectation that the G500 and G600 surpass the G450 and G550 peak margins. The built-in purpose-built facilities are coming down straight line
componenttext: The G650, nothing's going to come close to that for, I think, all the reasons that you understand. But it is our expectation that the G500 and G600 surpass the G450 and G550 peak margins. The built-in purpose-built facilities are coming down straight line, and we have, over that time, continued to perfect our manufacturing processes. So when we're up and really, really running, I think we're going to be better than those 2 legacy airplanes.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: Phebe, just to start off with Aerospace, you noted the good demand for the G650 in the quarter. Are you still going to stick with your plan to gradually ease 650 deliveries over time?

componenttext: Yes. So a little bit this year and then more in next year and the following year when 500s and 600s are in, as I say, full rate production with good margins.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. and then as a follow-up for GDIT. You mentioned a good book-to-bill in the quarter. How sustainable do you think this is? And what the expectation of that book-to-bill to revenues over time?
componenttext: Okay. and then as a follow-up for GDIT. You mentioned a good book-to-bill in the quarter. How sustainable do you think this is? And what the expectation of that book-to-bill to revenues over time?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, when we put something in firm backlog, it's a pretty shared conversion into revenue. But let me give you a little bit of context that I think helps to understand. So GDIT in the quarter had a 1.1:1  book-to-bill, and over the last 4 quarters, as I m
componenttext: Well, when we put something in firm backlog, it's a pretty shared conversion into revenue. But let me give you a little bit of context that I think helps to understand. So GDIT in the quarter had a 1.1:1  book-to-bill, and over the last 4 quarters, as I mentioned in my remarks, they had a 1:1. And now their win rate, they had demonstrated a win rate consecutively over those last 4 quarters between 70% and 75%. Against those performance indicators, you've got a budget that is growing by 5%, so I think this business is in very good stead for continued growth.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: Maybe a bigger strategy question, how are you thinking about Mission Systems, right? I mean their performance in the quarter was pretty good. And how do you think about growing that? Or it seems like it's subscale right now, right? Do you grow it, do you sell it? What are you going to do with it when you think about it?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So given its portfolio, I don't believe that it's subscale. If you think about what they really are is they are systems' integrator with a significant products business. They've got some long-term franchise programs on a number of them and those programs
componenttext: So given its portfolio, I don't believe that it's subscale. If you think about what they really are is they are systems' integrator with a significant products business. They've got some long-term franchise programs on a number of them and those programs are growing. So I like where they are. They've got some unique positioning, in fact, best-of-class positioning in a number of areas, in network security, fiber protection, accuracy and position navigation in a GPS environment, integration of systems on the ballistic-missile submarines and the fire control systems. So there is [indiscernible] -- these are programs that they've had for a long time, all of which are on growth trajectories. So I don't really see that -- them at subscale. And again, their margins are really quite nice. This is a good operating leverage company. I think they play nicely in the space they're in, and we're quite comfortable with it.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And maybe just one follow-up in Aerospace. Can you say when is the next available delivery slot for a 650?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And maybe just one follow-up in Aerospace. Can you say when is the next available delivery slot for a 650?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not going into that. I mean [indiscernible] we're really not tracking it that way. We've got a whole lot of new airplanes coming on. So those individual metrics become a little ]less meaningful. But you know, you need to think about what's really
componenttext: Yes, I'm not going into that. I mean [indiscernible] we're really not tracking it that way. We've got a whole lot of new airplanes coming on. So those individual metrics become a little ]less meaningful. But you know, you need to think about what's really unusual and unique about the Gulfstream portfolio is we have a family now of all brand-new airplanes, and when I say brand new, they're clean sheet. You know that better than anybody what that means. From scratch, all new. Nobody else has that. And that family is compelling, and we're seeing that in our consistent demand.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: On the Gulfstream, Phebe, are we seeing the trend for orders continue as strong in the second quarter here?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So we're off to a good start, but undergirding this, you raise a good question -- undergirding your question is really a I think more robust demand question. And I think I'll take this opportunity to help us think about demand a little bit more holistical
componenttext: So we're off to a good start, but undergirding this, you raise a good question -- undergirding your question is really a I think more robust demand question. And I think I'll take this opportunity to help us think about demand a little bit more holistically. It's kind of a folly to try to address demand prospectively. It's a little bit easier from a retrospective point of view as long as one's not too myopic about the data. So what does the data tell us, that the market for Gulfstream airplanes has been good over the last 12 months at a period of ramped up delivery. The book-to-bill in the quarter was 1.5:1 at Gulfstream and almost 1.1:1 for the trailing 12 months. This tell me that we're in a period of solid but not [indiscernible] demand. And I see nothing that is available to me at the moment that suggests a change in that picture. So that's how you ought to think about, as we go through the year, expectations about the demand environment.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick one on Marine. The revenues were somewhat less than I would've thought given the guidance of up 6% for the year and the margin was somewhat better. As we get increased revenues throughout the year, do we have the opportunity that the
componenttext: And then just a quick one on Marine. The revenues were somewhat less than I would've thought given the guidance of up 6% for the year and the margin was somewhat better. As we get increased revenues throughout the year, do we have the opportunity that the margin turns out to be higher than your 8.5%?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So we've always worked towards improved margin. But remember, the revenue is simply a question of timing and mix. And as we move from the Block III to the Block IV, we have accounted for those margin changes. As we see in every -- by the way, we see this
componenttext: So we've always worked towards improved margin. But remember, the revenue is simply a question of timing and mix. And as we move from the Block III to the Block IV, we have accounted for those margin changes. As we see in every -- by the way, we see this and you know this, that every one of our transitions, from one block to the other, because we down a continuous learning curve, and we have a -- each one of our contract at the same sort of target process and line of share line, so we always give back some of that goodness, appropriately so, to the U.S. Navy. But what does that mean? That means we've got to drive our operating performance relentlessly and continuously, and we've done that now for 20 years. So we will work very hard to consolidate and accelerate our learning on the Block IV. But at the moment, we're pretty comfortable with the guidance we gave you.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: Phebe, I wanted to trying to put a finer point on GDIT. I think publicly, it's been said that while '18 and '19 are relatively flat from a revenue standpoint, that the '18 to 2020 kind of growth rate you're still looking for is mid-single digits, is that correct?

componenttext: Yes, and I don't think we've given you a whole lot of specificity about '20. But I try to set some context for how to think about this growth profile. Without win rate, with the increasing budgets and their post-acquisition book-to-bill, we're in a very good place. So I can -- I look at this business as long-term good growth. And that budget was about 100 -- their addressable market budget was about $120 billion, a 5% increase -- almost 5% increase. That's pretty darn impressive. Good opportunity set.

componenttext: As a follow-up, Jason, any quantification you can give on what the drag was in Q1 from the delay on international side? And any sort of idea around timing. I know you were expecting to reverse this year, but is this more of a second half item that you're looking for?

componenttext: Yes. So the amount that's continued to push to the right, think of it as roughly $1 billion, David. That's what we're talking about. It's lapsed over from last year and continues to push to the right.

componenttext: And I think it's important to understand that these are in negotiations between 2 sovereign powers that are progressing, but they're very, very sensitive, as all diplomatic negotiations are. Progress is good, but slow. We do anticipate it resolving this year.

componenttext: Got it. So GDIT, obviously, you're looking for pretty good bookings. And if you win, things are going to be a lot better and if you lose, they won't to be as good as you're projecting. So how do you factor them?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, if you think about us, and you know us and you've known us for years, we are conservative when we look at opportunities. We give healthy discount rates. I think that's a good thing to do for -- internally for the business. And the forecast and guida
componenttext: Well, if you think about us, and you know us and you've known us for years, we are conservative when we look at opportunities. We give healthy discount rates. I think that's a good thing to do for -- internally for the business. And the forecast and guidance that we issue reflects that -- those discounted rates. So the beauty of a business with 7,000 contracts is that frankly no one is positive. But I'm comfortable that they live in their fair share. That said, we've approached those pipelines looking through a conservative prism.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Phebe, question on Combat, I guess. You mentioned some very positive comments regarding the fiscal '20 funding levels for some of the core platforms. I guess maybe just [indiscernible] for longer-term growth, how you're thinking about how those programs a
componenttext: Phebe, question on Combat, I guess. You mentioned some very positive comments regarding the fiscal '20 funding levels for some of the core platforms. I guess maybe just [indiscernible] for longer-term growth, how you're thinking about how those programs are shaping up  domestically? And then what some of the international opportunities that you're pursuing are for -- that could supplement that growth?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the U.S. Army is recapitalizing. After the hot wars, they had utilized a lot of their equipment. And as their budget was down rather [indiscernible], they did not have the resource to go and recapitalize, but they do now, and that's exactly what
componenttext: Sure. So the U.S. Army is recapitalizing. After the hot wars, they had utilized a lot of their equipment. And as their budget was down rather [indiscernible], they did not have the resource to go and recapitalize, but they do now, and that's exactly what they're doing. So they're modernizing the our existing fleet in addition to developing new potential platforms. And we -- that existing fleet is our program, right? Stryker and Abrams have seen considerable increases in their budget funding lines because the Army needs those vehicles. The Abrams remains an outstanding tank, and the upgrade in the version 4 really not your father's Abrams. It is a more capable, more survivable, more lethal system. As is Stryker. So we think those 2 core franchise programs are off to a very, very good start. We work very closely with our Army customers and understand their demands and their requirements and how they think about the war fight. And so we position ourselves and our investment dollars and also thinking about the art [indiscernible] possible for them on how we can help them meet their objective. That's certainly true on the franchise programs I've just talked about, but also on new programs. What is in the order of the possible, what's doable, how fast can you do it and what's it going to cost you? And the key there is to have the trust with your Army customer who believes that the estimate that you give them is reliable. So we've had a -- we're very aligned with our Army customer, know where they're headed, and I frankly like everything that I see here. And that's on the big vehicle programs. When I look at our munitions business, our munitions business is growing. I think we grew 10% in the quarter. And we've had a book-to-bill that's been very wholesome because as we increase our operational training temp, our munitions and armament increase demand. So outside the United States, in North America, outside the United States, we see some recapitalization in the U.K. and Canada, where we've had decade-long presence for both of those countries, throughout NATO and heavily Eastern in Europe. The world is getting a more dangerous place, and unfortunately, that creates a demand for our products. Our European Land Systems has multiple opportunities out -- throughout the former Soviet border states and Eastern Bloc and domestically and elsewhere. So threats drive funding and they drive the need for requirement. And unfortunately, we're living in a world with increased threat.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: Good quarter. Phebe, just a bigger question. I mean revenues were up, I think, 23% this quarter and profit was sort flattish. How do we think about that inflection in profit growth in excess of revenue growth? And timing of that in any, maybe impediment to that as you see?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So let's take the businesses into 2 distinct factors. Aerospace, I think we've just given you a pretty fulsome, and I won't walk you through that again, pretty fulsome explanation of the margin compression. And on the Defense side, it's really about mix.
componenttext: So let's take the businesses into 2 distinct factors. Aerospace, I think we've just given you a pretty fulsome, and I won't walk you through that again, pretty fulsome explanation of the margin compression. And on the Defense side, it's really about mix. When you're growing and you've got newer contracts coming in and you've got older contracts closing, you're going to have a mix issue, frankly. Because all of our Defense businesses are growing, we have some of that right now. So that will resolve continuing throughout the year and then into the future years, as we -- one thing you can absolutely rely on us for is superb operating performance. We are very good at improving what we control, and we control our own operations. So you can expect us to get better and better and better as time goes by.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So the FAA and us are targeting late June, but they've got a pretty rigorous process, so that may slip a week -- a couple of weeks or so. But I think importantly, that does not impact our deliveries, which is really the key underlying question. We have no
componenttext: So the FAA and us are targeting late June, but they've got a pretty rigorous process, so that may slip a week -- a couple of weeks or so. But I think importantly, that does not impact our deliveries, which is really the key underlying question. We have not seen any new regulations or any changes in the FAA oversight. So we work very closely with them, frankly, they're partners and ensuring that we deliver airplanes efficiently. And so we've got an additional workload, but so far, haven't really seen much of an impact.

componenttext: Okay. Great. And just as a follow-up, I noted the comments you made in the prepared remarks around the cost progress themselves and the quality there. componenttext: So cost is increasingly under control. The schedule, we've derisked a lot of the schedules. We're getting a lot of input from the manufacturing workforce, which will help us optimize our production. And again, we're very, very good at manufacturing. So a lot of that risk is definitely behind us and it's going to get better.

componenttext: So I wanted to follow-up on the question that Peter asked earlier about the combat business. And when we look at the budgets that have come out for Abrams over the past couple of years and what's being requested for 2020, it's kind of in the $2 billion-ish range, which seems like it's probably at least 2x, if not more, what Abram sales were last year. Should we be expecting Abrams sales over the next couple of years to advance to this level?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: You should expect them to advance. Think about it this way, for a while that in a period where the Army funding were seriously constrained that think plan was producing 1 tank a month. At the end of this year, we will be rolling out something summoned by the end of this year. So that obviously will drive revenue growth. And that backlog increase translates 1:1 into revenue.

componenttext: And just a follow-up on that [ 1.1 ], when you think about -- the point that you guys have made consistently in the past that the impact of mix shift towards domestic production on profitability in Combat, is that primarily an Abrams issue? headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: No, there is 2 things. There is mix of between domestic and international and there's also the mix issue driven by older contract and newer ones coming on board. So if Abrams ramps up, remember, we are also doing and overprotected firepower. We were one of the to downselect and so those are a -- and again, we've got to move down our learning curves. and that will something our performance over time.

componenttext: Sure. So the balance between the 2 is basically the contract work in process that's ongoing that you would expect in any contract of this size. That really is the delta there. If you have any additional questions, that can be reached at (703) 876-3117. Thank you very much.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019

componenttext: Good morning, everyone and welcome to the General Dynamics First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note, today's event is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to Howard Rubel, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jaime, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics First Quarter 2019 Conference Call. Any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks
componenttext: Thank you, Jaime, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics First Quarter 2019 Conference Call. Any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings. With that, it's my pleasure to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Howard, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported earnings of $2.56 per diluted share on revenue just shy of $9.3 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net income of $745 million. Revenue was up 23% against the first q
componenttext:
Thanks, Howard, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported earnings of $2.56 per diluted share on revenue just shy of $9.3 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net income of $745 million. Revenue was up 23% against the first quarter of 2018 due in large part to the acquisition of CSRA. However, without CSRA, revenue was up an impressive 9.6% on a purely organic basis. In fact, there was organic revenue growth across all 5 operating segments. 
EPS of $2.56 was $0.14 better than consensus. It would appear that revenue was some $400 million higher than anticipated by the sell-side, and operating earnings were about $40 million higher. Operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion were our just ahead of the year ago results despite modest declines in Aerospace, Marine and Com Systems. The results benefited from the combination of CSRA with GDIT.  
While the operating margin of 10.9% in the quarter was good, it did not compare favorably to last year's stellar first quarter of 13.4%, which was before the inclusion of amortization from the CSRA transaction. 
Net earnings are down $54 million over the same quarter in 2018. Higher interest expense, somewhat higher taxes were the cause of the lower net income. It follows that earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.09 below the first quarter 2018, a 3% drop. 
Apart from the impressive revenue growth, an important part of the story in the quarter was order intake and growth in backlog. Total backlog grew to $69.2 billion, an increase of $1.34 billion compared to the end of last year. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, the book-to-bill for the company was an impressive 1.2, broken down into 1.1:1 for Defense and 1.4:1 for Aerospace. 
Let me discuss each group and provide some color where appropriate. First Aerospace. Aerospace revenue of $2.2 billion was $415 million or 22.7% ahead of the year ago period. This was attributable in large part to the delivery of 7 G500s in the quarter and a solid increase in service revenue. The moderately lower operating earnings were related to the mix shift at Gulfstream from the delivery of the G500s. These planes carry the burden of the test program and retrofit as we previously advised. The margins on the aircraft will improve markedly through the year. 
At year-end, we had indicated that Aerospace margins for the first 2 quarters would be in the mid-14% range, up somewhat from the 14.1% rate in the final period of 2018. At 14.6%, the margin was fractionally better than that indication. Excluding the adverse impact of margins from preowned sales, margins would have been about 40 basis points better. Based on our delivery profile and cost improvement, we continue to expect overall margins to improve, particularly so in the second half of the year. 
On the order front, activity in the quarter was very good. The book-to-bill at Aerospace was 1.4:1 dollar denominated. The Gulfstream book-to-bill was even better. We grew the backlog for the G650 and also expanded the Gs 500 and 600 backlog. For the trailing 12 months, Aerospace book-to-bill was about 1.1:1. You can see more information on the quarter's deliveries and orders in Exhibit J to the press release.  
We anticipate that G600 will be certified late June, but timing is difficult to predict given the FAA's rigorous review process. Nonetheless, we expect certification of the 600 this quarter or early next. Deliveries will remain on track for the second half. 
While the pacing items for deliveries on the 500 and 600 is our ability to deliver nacelle, this is becoming less of an issue as you can discern from deliveries of the G500 in the fourth quarter and the last quarter. Nacelle costs are increasingly under control, and we are producing very good quality. We expect all schedule issues to be behind us by midyear. 
So forgive me this commercial plug, but earlier this month, the G650 shattered a record for speed and range demonstrating its unrivaled performance. The aircraft flew 8,379 nautical miles from Singapore to Tucson in 15 hours and 23 minutes, averaging Mach 0.85, beating the record inside just a few weeks earlier by the competitor's aircraft by 44 minutes. It is also interesting that the G650 traveled during that flight approximately 227 nautical miles further than the competitor's aircraft in considerably less time. This is to our knowledge the longest distance ever flown by any business aviation aircraft. This is of particular interest to customers who think that the range and speed at that range is of vital importance. 
Next, Combat. At Combat, revenue of $1.6 billion was 13.6% above the year ago quarter. On the other hand, operating earnings declined $18 million with an operating margin of 12.6%. Mix was a large factor behind the results. There was strong growth in the Abrams program and a ramp-up of Mobile Protected Firepower, another new program. Stryker volumes were down, but we ascribe that to timing. Munitions also delivered growth. We also took a onetime charge in the quarter related to the disposition of a legal dispute over the closeout of a lease at one of our former European operating sites. Absent that onetime item, earnings for this segment would have been up year-over-year. 
The diplomatic issues that have slowed production on the international vehicle program in Canada are in the process of being resolved. Once resolved, between the 2 countries, we will see a reduction in operating working capital and a corresponding increase in cash received. Backlog for this segment is lumpy with the fourth quarter traditionally seeing the highest order activity and the first quarter the slowest. This year was no exception. The $2.2 billion in orders received in Q4 followed by the approximately $1.2 billion in orders received this quarter is of good line of sight for our production planning and continuous improvement methodology. 
Of note, Stryker backlog grew in the first quarter, and the Army added funding to the SEPv4, the next generation of the Abrams' main battle tank. Stryker is a very flexible platform, and the Army continues to find additional systems and weapons that we are integrating onto the vehicles. Integration of new capabilities onto our vehicles leverages our investment. Our intimate knowledge of the platform ensures that the Army receives its programs reliably and affordably. 
We also continue to see opportunities to expand the ordnance and tactical munition business as the Army refreshes its ordnance and ammo stockpiles. We continue to have significant international opportunities throughout NATO and Eastern Europe as well as the Pacific regions. 
Next, Marine Systems. Marine revenues of $2.1 billion was up slightly and operating earnings of $180 million were down $4 million against the year ago quarter. Operating margins were 8.7% with our guidance for the year at 8.5%. We are modestly ahead of target. We have delivered the 17th ship of the Virginia class program and have another 11 in various stages of construction. With respect to Columbia, we are 97% complete with the detailed design and nearly 43% complete with the construction design drawings. We will be at 83% complete at the start of construction, far in excess of historical design completion metrics for any class of warships. We have begun long-lead material construction on Columbia and will begin full construction of the first ship late next year.  
In response to the significant increase in demand from our Navy customer across all 3 of our shipyards, we continue to invest in each of our yards with particular emphasis on Electric Boat to prepare for the higher production associated with Block V of the Virginia program and the new Columbia ballistic-missile submarine. As you may recall, both Columbia and the Block V represent a significant increased in size and performance requiring additional manufacturing capacity and different logistics infrastructure to transport the larger modules from Quonset Point to the waterfront in Groton for final assembly and test. 
CapEx in 2018 for Marine Systems was $243 million, more than double its depreciation for the year. For 2019, we again expect the Marine segment to command the largest share of our capital budget, about half of our entire CapEx. So suffice it to say that we are poised to support our Navy customers as they seek to increase the size of their fleet. 
Next, Information Technology. For the quarter, IT generated revenue of $2.2 billion and operating earnings of $156 million with an operating margin of 7.2%. Since the numbers for the first quarter 2018 did not include CSRA, comparisons to the year ago quarter are not meaningful. 
Revenue of $2.2 billion is up by over $1 billion, but is down about $200 million sequentially, over half of which is attributable to the divestiture of the call centers and the remaining to the winding down of several mature programs replaced by the ramp-up of new programs. Margin of 7.2% is lower than Q4 due to mix, but a bit better than Q2 and Q3 of 2018. 
If you look at our EBITDA margin, it is 12.4% including state and local taxes in the operating results. If these taxes were carried below the line, as in the case for most competitors in this segment, it would add approximately 50 basis points to our results. This places the business in the best-in-class category for its industry. 
The integration has gone well and is a bit ahead of our plan we put in place last year. We are taking the best of the 2 legacy companies and building a highly competitive enterprise with the scale and the resources to create value for our customers and our shareholders. GDIT's book-to-bill for the quarter was 1.1:1 and for the trailing 4 quarters, it is over 1:1. This business is growing and is positioned for growth going forward. 
The first quarter includes some notable wins, a $490 million contract from DISA to support Pentagon network infrastructure, a $125 million for helicopter training and simulation at Fort Rucker, $580 million for several classified programs and a myriad of additional wins across the portfolio. 
Finally, for Mission Systems, revenue rose by 5.5% compared to the year ago quarter while operating earnings of $148 million were $2 million higher than the first quarter of last year, with a 50 basis point decrement in operating margins attributable solely to mix. Book-to-bill for the quarter was 1x following 1:1 book-to-bill for this -- for each of the last 2 years. As you can see, we ended the quarter with the backlog of $5.3 billion, essentially level with the prior quarter and with the year ago quarter. Demand was broad-based across many of their space and naval programs. Army ground systems activity was particularly strong. 
So in my view, we are off to a good start to the year. The story in the first quarter was about revenue and backlog growth. Orders of $10.7 billion across our businesses provide us with good operational visibility. Our ongoing focus on productivity provides the opportunity to deliver very good results. As we begin this quarter, we expect our second quarter performance to be very similar to the first quarter from an EPS perspective. 
You may recall that we do not, as a practice, change guidance at the end of the first quarter. It is our practice to give you a full review of our expectations at midyear -- at midpoint during the year. Suffice it to say that we are a bit ahead of the operating plan upon which our guidance was based. As always, we will work to consolidate our improvement and strive to continue to improve our results. 
Let me turn this over to Jason for additional commentary and then take your questions.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. Net interest expense in the quarter was $117 million versus $27 million in the first quarter of 2018. The increase in 2019 is due to the debt we issued to finance the acquisition of CSRA. We are also carrying more comme
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. Net interest expense in the quarter was $117 million versus $27 million in the first quarter of 2018. The increase in 2019 is due to the debt we issued to finance the acquisition of CSRA. We are also carrying more commercial paper than anticipated due to delayed payments on one of our large international vehicle programs in Canada. Our free cash flow of negative $976 million was impacted by these payment delays and as we've discussed previously, this is a timing item. 
On the capital deployment front, capital expenditures of $181 million in the quarter were up about 75% from the year ago quarter as we invest in our shipyards to support the significant growth that's on the horizon. We still expect this year to be the peak at approximately 3% of revenues and returning to the 2% range thereafter. 
In the quarter, we paid $268 million in dividends, and we spent $86 million on the repurchase of 525,000 of our shares. We plan to acquire enough shares in 2019 to ensure there is no dilution from the exercise of employee stock options. Otherwise, we anticipate deploying the balance of our free cash flow this year to pay down our short-term borrowings. 
We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $673 million on the balance sheet and a net debt position of $12.9 billion. Our effective tax rate was 18.6% for the quarter, which is consistent with our full year tax rate guidance. As Phebe noted, order activity and backlog were a particularly strong story in the quarter, as 4 of our 5 segments posted a book-to-bill of 1:1 or greater even as we grew almost 10% organically. 
On that note, I think it bears a reminder that not all companies report book-to-bill on the same basis. We calculate this measure based on the firm backlog as reported under generally accepted accounting principles excluding the value associated with IDIQ contracts. That's, of course, most relevant to Mission Systems and GDIT, each of which had a book-to-bill of 1:1 or greater even under the more conservative GAAP definition. 
We finished the quarter with a total backlog of $69.2 billion, that's up 2% over year-end 2018 and up 11% over this time a year ago. The total potential contract value including options and IDIQ contracts was $103 billion consistent with year-end and up almost 18% over a year ago. 
As one final item I'd like to highlight, we adopted the new lease accounting standard effective January 1 of this year on a perspective basis. We recorded a $1.4 billion liability for our operating leases along with a corresponding asset. This creates a visible change in our other assets and liabilities on the balance sheet, but otherwise has no impact on our net earnings or cash flows. 
Howard, that concludes my remarks, I'll turn it back over to you for the Q&A.
